chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The solution definition file contains instructions for building Linux operating solutions for use in installing client machines. It defines solution content and configuration, including name, version, and architecture; package repository locations; which packages to include; and the locations of configuration scripts, files and custom graphics. CentOS Studio uses the solution file to assemble, create and publish the solution. Other programs, such as YUM, Anaconda, and RPM use files created by CentOS Studio to install and update the solution on the client system.

The solution definition file is a text-based file in XML format. Within the file are a series of top-level elements that equate to modules, or steps, within the solution build process. These elements, in turn, contain their own attributes and elements. There are three required top-level elements: , , and ; all other top-level elements are optional. Top-level elements can appear in the solution file in any order. Indentation is for readability purposes only.
The solution definition file has full support of XML Inclusions (XIncludes). Please refer to the XInclude Technical Report for more information.
A solution definition file can be located in any local directory and invoked from the command line using the command centosstudio followed by the full or relative pathname to the file, such as:

section.title: Example Solution Definition
section.para: Here is a basic example solution definition based on CentOS 5.

informalexample.programlisting:
<solution>
<main> <name>samba</name> <version>5</version> <arch>i386</arch> </main>
<repos> <repo id="base"> <name>CentOS-$version - Base</name> <baseurl>http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/</baseurl> </repo> <repo id="updates"> <name>CentOS-$version - Updates</name> <baseurl>http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/updates/i386/</baseurl> </repo> </repos>
<packages> <group repoid="base">core</group> <group repoid="base">smb-server</group> </packages>
</solution>
